TEXT:
Chief Complaint: Nausea, NSTEMI, s/p Cath lab with 2 bare metal stents
   to SVG-OM
   24 Hour Events:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8912**] is a 70 yo man with CAD s/p CABX [**2192**] (LIMA-LAD, SVT to
   RPDA and SVG to OM), diastolic CHF, PVD who was admitted to vascular
   surgery for L fem-[**Doctor Last Name 114**] bypass on [**5-4**] for thrombosed R popliteal
   aneurysm.  His operation was uncomplicated, but post-op at 3am he
   developed nausea & diaphoresis.  EKG showed lateral ST depressions &
   STE in III and aVR.  In this setting he developed hypoxia (SaO2 high
   80's on 100% NRB), & hypotension to the 80's for several hours.  First
   set of CE's were markedly positive with CK 1192 and trop 0.8.
   Cardiology was consulted who recommended urgent cardiac
   catheterization.
   .
   In the cath lab, he was found to have an acute occlusion of his SVG to
   OM1 graft.  Clot was suctioned from the graft and 2 bare metal stents
   were placed with good effect.  His BP improved with this intervention
   and he began making tood urine.  The rest of his coronaries showed
   native disease similar to prior cath.
   .
   On arrival to the CCU, vitals 97.1 126/64 73 26 87% on 4L.  Pt was
   given 40mg IV lasix and put on a non-rebreather with improvement of his
   sats to mid-upper-90's.  Pt was loaded with plavix and continued on
   integrelin drip.
   Allergies:
   Lipitor (Oral) (Atorvastatin Calcium)
   Arthralgia/Arth
   Ciprofloxacin
   Unknown;
   Trimethoprim
   Unknown;
   Bactrim (Oral) (Sulfamethoxazole/Trimethoprim)
   Rash;
   Atenolol
   Lightheadedness
   Crestor (Oral) (Rosuvastatin Calcium)
   Unknown;
   Zetia (Oral) (Ezetimibe)
   Unknown;
   Vicodin (Oral) (Hydrocodone Bit/Acetaminophen)
   Unknown;
   Cephalexin
   Unknown;
   Amlodipine
   Lightheadedness
   Quinapril
   Lightheadedness
   Spironolactone
   Unknown;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Eptifibatide (Integrilin) - 2 mcg/Kg/min
   Other ICU medications:
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   70M thrombosed R popliteal aneurysm s/p R CFA-PT(R cephalic) [**5-4**]
   PMH:
   # Hypertension
   # Hypercholesterolemia
   # CABG x 3 [**2192**]: LIMA to LAD, SVG to RPDA, SVG to OM
   # Diastolic heart failure
   # CKD with baseline Creatinine:1.4
   # PVD:
   # Left CEA [**1-8**]
   # Abdominal aortic aneurysm 5.0 x 4.0 with eccentric mural thrombus
   s/p endovascular repair on [**2198-1-8**] c/b postoperative pneumonia and
   herpes zoster.
   # RAS s/p renal stenting, hypogastric coiling [**2198-1-2**]
   # Sleep apnea- has CPAP but does not use frequently
   # Prior smoking- 150 pack years
   # Orcheitis [**1-/2198**]
   # Left testicular surgery [**2196**]
   # Gout--in record, pt denies
   # Kidney stones
   # Gerd
   # Umbilical hernia repair [**4-11**]
   .
   MEDS:
   Isosorbide monontirate 30mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Omeprazole 20mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Allopurinol 300mg daily
   Aspirin 81mg 2 tablets daily
   Magnesium Oxide 400mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Metoprolol succinate 50mg
 tablet [**Hospital1 **]
   Hydralazine 10mg TID
   Furosemide 20mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Potassium 20meq daily
   Study medication ? from Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2731**] for Tra2P TIMI 50
   .
   Allergies: Lipitor, Cipro, Trimeth/Sulfa, Atenolol, Crestor, Zetia,
   Vicodin, hydrchlorthiazide, Cephalexin, Amlodipine, Spironolactone,
   Quinapril
   .
   Social History: Former heavy smoker, 150 pack years
   .
   Family History: Unknown
   .
   Cardiac enzymes: CK 1192, CK-MB 219, CK, trop 0.82
   [**2198-1-8**] p-MIBI
   Partially reversible mid-anterior wall mild defect. The calculated
   left ventricular ejection fraction is 48%.
   .
   Cardiac catheterization: [**2198-5-5**] -
   Coronary Angiography - right dominant
   LMCA:  subtotally occluded
   LAD:  proximally occluded; distal vessel fills via LIMA
   LCX:  diffuse proximal/mid disease; SVG to major OM seen to be occluded
   RCA:  not injected; known severely diffusely diseased
   SVG-OM: proximally occluded with acute appearance of thrombus
   LIMA-LAD:  normal
   SVG-RPDA:  mild disease
   .
   SVG-OM - dilated and stented with overlapping 4.5x28 and 5.0x18 Ultra
   stents with no residual, normal flow.
   .
   [**1-/2198**] ECHO
   The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is severe symmetric left
   ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is normal.
   Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). Transmitral Doppler
   and tissue velocity imaging are consistent with Grade I (mild) LV
   diastolic dysfunction. The gradient increased with the Valsalva
   manuever. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are
   normal. The aortic root is moderately dilated at the sinus level. The
   aortic arch is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly
   thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Mild (1+) aortic
   regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are moderately
   thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. No mitral regurgitation
   is seen. The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests impaired
   relaxation. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. The
   pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is an
   anterior space which most likely represents a fat pad.
   .
   IMPRESSION: Severe left ventricular hypertrophy with hyperdynamic left
   ventricular systolic function. Mild diastolic dysfunction. Mild
   inducible outflow tract greadient. Moderately dilated aortic root. Mild
   aortic regurgitation.
   .
   [**2198-5-4**] CXR
   Portable AP chest radiograph was compared to [**2198-1-10**].
   The internal jugular line tip is at the level of low SVC. The patient
   is in mild volume overload. Otherwise, no significant changes have been
   demonstrated. No pneumothorax is seen.
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:
   Constitutional: No(t) Fever
   Ear, Nose, Throat: No(t) Epistaxis
   Cardiovascular: No(t) Chest pain, No(t) Palpitations, No(t) Edema,
   No(t) Tachycardia
   Nutritional Support: NPO
   Respiratory: No(t) Cough, Wheeze
   Genitourinary: Foley
   Musculoskeletal: left arm pain
   Integumentary (skin): No(t) Jaundice, No(t) Rash
   Heme / Lymph: No(t) Anemia, No(t) Coagulopathy
   Neurologic: No(t) Numbness / tingling
   Psychiatric / Sleep: No(t) Agitated
   Allergy / Immunology: No(t) Immunocompromised

        [image002.jpg]
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8912**] is a 70 yo man with CAD s/p CABG in [**2192**], diastolic CHF,
   severe PVD who presents with post-operative NSTEMI & CHF.  Pt taken to
   cath lab with placement of 2 bare metal stents to SVG--OM graft.
   .
   # NSTEMI/CAD: presenting with likely ACS from acute occlusion of SVG.
   Two Ultra bare metal stents place in SVG-OM.  Pt transferred on ICU on
   integrelin.
   - aspirin
   - plavix load, then daily
   - uptitrate metoprolol to 25mg po tid
   - recheck lipid panel and address numerous statin allergies, pt
   currently written for simvastatin but had been refusing on the vascular
   service
   - will start low dose ACE
   - post-cath check at 1:30
   - 2pm post-cath labs
   - ECHO on arrival to ICU for evaluation of mitral regurg in setting of
   ichemic episode
   .
   # Diastolic CHF: with acute exacerbation likely related to volume
   overload + ischemia, EF > 55%
   - diurese with goal - 1-2L today
   - wean O2 as tolerated
   - ECHO on arrival to the ICU
   - atrovent for wheezing
   .
   # Hypertension - on metoprolol and hydralazine at baseline
   - titrate metoprolol for tight BP control
   - start low dose ACE inhibitor
   .
   # Rhythm - Sinus
   .
   # PVD s/p bypass - [**2198-5-4**] L SFA-PT (R cephalic)
   - vascular following, appreciate recs
   - continue BBlocker and statin
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia - continue statin if patient will allow
   - further discuss ongoing statin therapy with patient
   - uptitrate statin
   .
   # CKD - baseline Cr 1.5, Pt received dye load with cath, however, have
   to hold post-cath fluids [**2-5**] pulmonary edema and CHF
   - continue to monitor creatinine and urine output
   .
   # Obstructive Sleep Apnea - has history and home CPAP machine with him
   - CPAP nightly on home settings
   .
   # FEN/GI - NPO for now while somnolent, once flatus+ can advance diet
   per vasc surgeries recs, currently no bowel sounds, bowel regimen,
   replete lytes prn
   .
   # PPX - sc heparin, no pneumoboot on left leg [**2-5**] new graft, IS,
   continue PPI
   .
   # Access - RIJ, A-line
   .
   # Code - Full Code
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2198-5-5**] 11:40 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2198-5-5**] 11:41 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2198-5-5**] 11:42 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), diastolic heart failure, and peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) after undergoing vascular surgery for a thrombosed right popliteal aneurysm. Post-operatively, he developed nausea, diaphoresis, and hypoxia, leading to a diagnosis of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and cardiac catheterization. The catheterization revealed an acute occlusion of the saphenous vein graft (SVG) to the obtuse marginal (OM) branch, which was successfully treated with two bare metal stents. The patient was started on aspirin, plavix, and metoprolol, and was transferred to the ICU for further management.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ischemic complications: The patient's SVG-OM graft was occluded, which could lead to further ischemia and potential complications such as infarction or arrhythmias.
2. Heart failure: The patient has a history of diastolic heart failure and may be at risk for further exacerbation due to volume overload, ischemia, or other factors.
3. Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension and may be at risk for further elevation due to the stress of surgery and other factors.
4. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient has a history of PVD and may be at risk for further complications such as graft failure or limb ischemia.
5. Chronic kidney disease: The patient has a history of CKD and may be at risk for further decline in renal function due to the use of contrast media and other factors.
6. Obstructive sleep apnea: The patient has a history of sleep apnea and may be at risk for further exacerbation due to the use of sedatives or other factors.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea due to the use of medications or other factors.
8. Respiratory complications: The patient is at risk for respiratory complications such as pneumonia or respiratory failure due to the use of sedatives or other factors.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's cardiac enzymes and troponin levels to assess for further ischemia or infarction.
2. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust medications as necessary to maintain tight control.
3. Monitor the patient's peripheral circulation and assess for any signs of limb ischemia or graft failure.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medications as necessary to minimize the risk of further decline.
5. Monitor the patient's sleep apnea and adjust treatment as necessary to minimize the risk of further exacerbation.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal function and adjust treatment as necessary to minimize the risk of gastrointestinal complications.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory function and adjust treatment as necessary to minimize the risk of respiratory complications.
8. Consider further testing such as echocardiography or stress testing to assess the patient's cardiac function and identify any potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient, a 70-year-old man, is admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (STEMI) post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and chronic diastolic heart failure. He has a history of peripheral vascular disease (PVD) and is currently experiencing regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 82 beats per minute, blood pressure of 143/79 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98% on nasal cannula oxygen. His respiratory support includes a nasal cannula with 4 liters of oxygen.

The patient's physical examination reveals a normal cardiovascular examination, with a normal cardiac rhythm and no murmurs. His peripheral vascular examination shows a diminished left dorsalis pedis pulse and a normal right dorsalis pedis pulse.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating cardiac damage, and mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction. His creatinine level has increased to 1.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 29 mg/dL, indicating acute kidney injury.

The patient's medical plan includes the continuation of integrillin, aspirin, and simvastatin, as well as the addition of atorvastatin and clopidogrel to reduce the risk of further cardiac events. He is also receiving diuretics to manage his heart failure and has been advised to wean off oxygen therapy as tolerated.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening of cardiac function, leading to further heart failure and increased risk of mortality.
2. Development of acute kidney injury, which may require further management and potentially lead to end-stage renal disease.
3. Increased risk of bleeding due to the use of anticoagulant medications and the presence of a catheter in the femoral artery.
4. Potential for respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure, due to the patient's underlying cardiac disease and the use of oxygen therapy.
5. Risk of gastrointestinal bleeding due to the use of anticoagulant medications and the patient's history of gastrointestinal disease.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and manage potential complications and to optimize his cardiac function and overall health.

Summary:

The patient, a 70-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU for post-operative management after undergoing femoral bypass surgery, coronary artery bypass grafting, and placement of two bare metal stents to the saphenous vein graft. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, and severe peripheral vascular disease. He is currently experiencing acute coronary syndrome with new regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, acute on chronic diastolic/systolic congestive heart failure, and hypertension.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4C, heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 143/79 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 21 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98%. He is receiving oxygen therapy through a nasal cannula.

The patient's physical examination reveals a normal-sized heart with mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction. He has a mild to moderate mitral regurgitation and mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. His neurological examination is normal, and he has no signs of peripheral edema.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating myocardial injury. His creatinine level is 1.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen level is 26 mg/dL. His white blood cell count is 14.7 x 10^9/L, and his platelet count is 218 x 10^9/L.

The patient is receiving various medications, including heparin sodium, aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, and metoprolol. He is also receiving diuretics, vasodilators, and antihypertensives.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, and new regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction increases his risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and myocardial infarction.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and acute respiratory distress syndrome increases his risk of respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, acute respiratory failure, and respiratory arrest.
3. Renal complications: The patient's elevated creatinine level and history of chronic kidney disease increase his risk of renal complications, such as acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease progression, and end-stage renal disease.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of peptic ulcer disease and use of anticoagulants increases his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.
5. Infection complications: The patient's history of catheter placement and use of antibiotics increases his risk of infection complications, such as sepsis, septic shock, and endocarditis.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of stroke and use of anticoagulants increases his risk of neurological complications, such as stroke, transient ischemic attack, and bleeding.

Overall, the patient is at high risk of developing various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are essential to prevent and treat these complications.

This could indicate ongoing respiratory failure, which could lead to further complications such as pneumonia, respiratory acidosis, or even respiratory failure.

7. Hematological complications: The patient's lab results show a slight decrease in hemoglobin and hematocrit, which could indicate ongoing bleeding or blood loss. This could lead to further complications such as anemia, bleeding disorders, or even blood transfusion reactions.

Overall, the patient is at risk for a range of medical complications, including cardiac, respiratory, renal, neurological, infectious, gastrointestinal, and hematological complications.

   - aspirin

   - pt with elevated lipid panel, would benefit from statin.  Will

   - cont captopril
   .

   - cont to diurese with goal - 1-2L today
   - wean O2 as tolerated

   .

   - cont captopril

   - uptitrate statin; pt written for simvastatin 20mg po daily

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old man with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, diastolic CHF, and severe PVD, who presented with post-operative NSTEMI and CHF. He was taken to the cath lab, where two bare metal stents were placed in the SVG-OM graft. The patient is currently being treated with integrelin, aspirin, plavix, metoprolol, captopril, and atrovent. He has a history of allergies to various medications, including lipitor, ciprofloxacin, and trimethoprim. The patient's lab results show elevated CK and CKMB levels, as well as troponin-T levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Ischemia and infarct due to acute occlusion of the SVG
	* Regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with infero-lateral akinesis
	* Mild to moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to volume overload and ischemia
	* Pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
3. Neurological complications:
	* Cerebral edema or ischemia due to cardiac complications
	* Seizures or altered mental status due to electrolyte imbalance or medication side effects
4. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to anticoagulation therapy or gastrointestinal ulcers
	* Constipation or bowel obstruction due to medication side effects or decreased mobility
5. Renal complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to volume overload, ischemia, or medication side effects
	* Chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression due to underlying disease and medication side effects
6. Infection complications:
	* Sepsis or septic shock due to bacteremia or pneumonia
	* Wound infection or surgical site infection due to surgical trauma or compromised immune system
7. Bleeding complications:
	* Hemorrhagic complications due to anticoagulation therapy or gastrointestinal bleeding
	* Blood transfusion reactions or allergic reactions to blood products

   and was present during the physical examination noted above.  I concur
   with the assessment and treatment plan as outline above.   Mr.
   [**Known lastname 8912**] is a 70 year old man who developed a posterior STEMI
   following vascular surgery repair of his left popliteal aneurysm.
   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated a thrombotic occlusion of the SVG
   to the OMB and two bare metal stent were placed.  He received aspirin,
   plavix and integrillin.  He developed recurrent nausea immediately
   after the procedure associated with persistent ST depressions, but this
   resolved.  He has multiple intolerances to statins and Zetia and has an
   LDL cholesterol = 197.  As a outpatient, we might consider the addition
   of cholestyramine as a bile acid sequestrant.  This afternoon, he
   developed [**3-13**] recurrent pain associated with some deepening of the ST
   segment depression.  This was controlled with IV NTG and he is now
   painfree.  We will cycle his enzymes and consider repeat
   catheterization for refractory pain or elevation of his cardiac
   enzymes.   Our plan is outlined above and involved implementation of IV
   heparin and NTG and continuation of his aspirin and clopidogrel.  This
   plan was communicated with the patient and all questions were
   addressed.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU for post-operative management of femoral bypass surgery, with a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and chronic diastolic heart failure. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), peripheral vascular disease (PVD), and hypercholesterolemia.

The patient underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed a thrombotic occlusion of the saphenous vein graft (SVG) to the obtuse marginal (OM) branch, and two bare metal stents were placed. The patient received aspirin, clopidogrel, and integrillin post-catheterization.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.8C (98.3F), HR 82 bpm, BP 143/79 mmHg, RR 21 breaths/min, SpO2 98%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is receiving IV heparin and NTG for prophylaxis and treatment of potential complications.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 306 mL of fluids since 12 AM, with a negative balance of -2,294 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving oxygen via a nasal cannula at 4 L/min.
* Physical examination: The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender, with bowel sounds present. The patient has no edema and healing incisions on the right upper and left lower extremities.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* Complete blood count (CBC): WBC 14.7 K/uL, Hct 42.7%, Plt 218 K/uL
* Electrolytes: Na 135 mEq/L, K 3.4 mEq/L, Cl 96 mEq/L
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 26 mg/dL
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.7 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 8.83 ng/mL
* CK/CKMB: 1266/246 IU/L
* LDL/HDL: 197/44 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac complications: The patient is at risk for cardiac complications such as recurrent STEMI, ventricular arrhythmias, and cardiogenic shock.
* Respiratory complications: The patient is at risk for respiratory complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory failure.
* Renal complications: The patient is at risk for renal complications such as acute kidney injury (AKI), chronic kidney disease (CKD), and electrolyte imbalance.
* Bleeding complications: The patient is at risk for bleeding complications such as hemorrhagic shock, bleeding from the surgical site, and gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Infection complications: The patient is at risk for infection complications such as wound infection, pneumonia, and sepsis.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* IV heparin and NTG for prophylaxis and treatment of potential complications
* Aspirin and clopidogrel for antiplatelet therapy
* Integrillin for post-catheterization management
* Statin therapy for hypercholesterolemia
* Cholestyramine as an alternative to statin therapy
* Diuresis goal of 500 mL negative to improve fluid balance
* Weaning of oxygen as tolerated
* Atrovent nebs as needed for respiratory support
* Telemetry monitoring for cardiac rhythm disturbances
* Vascular follow-up for PVD
* Monitoring of creatinine and urine output for renal function
* Advance diet and bowel regimen for gastrointestinal support

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but he is at risk for various medical complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, s/p coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diastolic heart failure, and severe peripheral vascular disease. He was admitted for femoral bypass and presented with post-operative posterior ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and acute on chronic heart failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiac markers are trending down, but he continues to experience chest pain associated with standard deviation (STD) waves on the electrocardiogram (ECG).
* He has a history of allergic reactions to certain medications, including Lipitor, Ciprofloxacin, and Atenolol.
* He is currently receiving heparin infusion, nitroglycerin, and simvastatin, and is being monitored for potential adverse reactions.
* His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1C, heart rate of 68 beats per minute, blood pressure of 101/56 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%.
* His physical examination reveals a soft and non-tender abdomen, with no evidence of edema or erythema at the incision sites.
* His laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, but his creatinine and urine output are within normal limits.
* He is at risk for delirium, and his mental status is described as "delirious/disoriented" with no fever or leukocytosis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Recurrent graft occlusion, which could lead to further cardiovascular events.
* Acute kidney injury or worsening chronic kidney disease due to hypotension, heart failure, or medications.
* Hypotension or hypertension, which could be exacerbated by medications or underlying medical conditions.
* Delirium or toxic encephalopathy, which could be caused by medications, electrolyte imbalances, or underlying medical conditions.
* Worsening heart failure, which could lead to pulmonary edema, cardiogenic shock, or death.
* Recurrent or worsening peripheral vascular disease, which could lead to further cardiovascular events or limb ischemia.

To mitigate these risks, the patient's treatment plan should focus on optimizing his cardiac function, managing his blood pressure, and preventing or treating complications such as delirium, hypotension, or electrolyte imbalances.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old man admitted to the ICU for femoral bypass surgery with post-operative STEMI and CHF. The patient has a history of CAD, diastolic CHF, severe PVD, and CKD.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 37.1C, Tcurrent 37.1C, HR 68 bpm, BP 101/56 mmHg, RR 26 inspirations per minute, SpO2 97%.
* Laboratory results: WBC 14.7, Hct 42.7, Plt 54, Cr 1.7, TropT 8.83, Glucose 134.
* Cardiovascular status: Patient has acute occlusion of SVG-OM1 with placement of 2 BMS, ECHO with new regional WMA, LVEF 40-45%.
* Respiratory status: Patient is on nasal cannula oxygen 2L, SpO2 97%.
* Renal status: Patient has CKD, with baseline Cr 1.5, elevated to 1.7 in the setting of recent dye load with cath.
* Other medical conditions: Patient has history of hypercholesterolemia, poorly controlled lipid panel, obstructive sleep apnea, and FEN/GI.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Cardiac complications: Acute coronary syndrome, cardiac tamponade, cardiogenic shock, and arrhythmias.
* Respiratory complications: Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory failure.
* Renal complications: Acute kidney injury (AKI), chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression, and electrolyte imbalance.
* Gastrointestinal complications: Gastrointestinal bleeding, nausea and vomiting, and bowel obstruction.
* Neurological complications: Stroke, seizures, and encephalopathy.

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, the following plan should be implemented:

* Continue statin therapy and monitor for ADR.
* Consider cholestyramine as an alternative to statin therapy.
* Continue to monitor creatinine and urine output.
* Hold post-cath fluids and continue to monitor for pulmonary edema and CHF.
* Continue to monitor for signs of STEMI and CHF.
* Continue to monitor for signs of respiratory failure and pneumonia.
* Continue to monitor for signs of AKI and CKD progression.
* Continue to monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and bowel obstruction.
* Continue to monitor for signs of stroke, seizures, and encephalopathy.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan as necessary to prevent and manage potential medical complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, and is being treated for acute coronary syndrome.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.8F, heart rate of 68 bpm, blood pressure of 101/56 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 97% on nasal cannula at 2L.

The patient's lab results show:

* Hemoglobin: 11.3 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 42.7%
* Platelet count: 54,000
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 8.83 ng/mL
* CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 162/30/8.83 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's medical history includes:

* Coronary artery disease
* Peripheral vascular disease
* Previous treatment with statins, including Lipitor, Crestor, and Zetia
* Previous treatment with beta blockers, including Atenolol
* Previous treatment with ACE inhibitors, including Quinapril
* Previous treatment with diuretics, including Spironolactone

The patient's current medications include:

* Heparin sodium infusion
* Nitroglycerin infusion
* Protonix
* Omeprazole
* Lasix
* Statin (changed to cholestyramine)

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias due to changes in electrolyte levels
* Increased risk of bleeding due to heparin therapy
* Worsening of peripheral vascular disease
* Development of stress ulcers due to prolonged ICU stay
* Increased risk of delirium and confusion due to sedative medications and ICU environment

The patient's plan includes:

* Continued monitoring of vital signs and lab results
* Adjustment of medications as necessary
* Further evaluation of cardiac function and peripheral vascular disease
* Consideration of further treatment options, such as coronary angiography and percutaneous coronary intervention.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for post-operative posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and acute on chronic diastolic/acute systolic heart failure. The patient is currently admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management.

The patient's condition has been improving, with cardiac markers trending down, and nitroglycerin infusion restarted overnight. The patient's blood pressure is borderline, and antihypertensives are being used with caution. The patient is also experiencing delirium, which is being managed with haloperidol.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening of heart failure: The patient's heart failure is acute on chronic, and the patient's cardiac markers are trending down. However, the patient's condition may worsen if the heart failure is not adequately managed.
2. Graft occlusion: The patient's SVG-OM1 graft is occluded, which may lead to recurrent chest pain and further complications.
3. Mitral valve involvement: The patient's mitral valve may be involved in the heart failure, which may require further evaluation and management.
4. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's hypercholesterolemia is poorly controlled, which may lead to further cardiovascular complications.
5. Chronic kidney disease: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which may indicate chronic kidney disease. The patient's urine output is also decreased, which may indicate acute kidney injury.
6. Delirium: The patient's delirium is being managed with haloperidol, but the patient may require further evaluation and management to determine the underlying cause of the delirium.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen requirement is increasing, which may indicate respiratory failure. The patient's chest pain is also worsening, which may be related to respiratory failure.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old man who underwent vascular surgery repair of his left popliteal aneurysm and developed a posterior STEMI. He was admitted to the ICU for post-op care and management of his cardiac condition. The patient has been experiencing chest pain, which has improved with treatment. He has also been experiencing nausea and has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.8C, heart rate of 68 bpm, and blood pressure of 101/56 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 26 inspirations per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 97%. His physical examination is normal, with no signs of cardiac tamponade or respiratory distress.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.7 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 11.3 g/dL, and a platelet count of 54 x 10^9/L. His troponin-T level is 8.83 ng/mL, and his creatine kinase (CK) level is 162 IU/L. His electrolyte levels are normal, with a potassium level of 4.0 mEq/L, a sodium level of 136 mEq/L, and a chloride level of 99 mEq/L.

The patient's medical history includes coronary artery disease, diastolic heart failure, and severe peripheral vascular disease. He has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and has a history of recurrent graft occlusion.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac condition is unstable, and he is at risk for further complications such as cardiac tamponade, arrhythmias, and heart failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory rate is increased, and he is at risk for respiratory failure.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding complications.
4. Renal complications: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is at risk for further kidney damage.
5. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of delirium and is at risk for further neurological complications such as seizures and stroke.

Based on the patient's condition, it is recommended that he continue to receive close monitoring and treatment in the ICU. He should be closely monitored for any signs of cardiac, respiratory, gastrointestinal, renal, or neurological complications.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for posterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The patient is currently admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for post-operative management and treatment of acute on chronic diastolic and acute systolic heart failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1C, heart rate of 68 beats per minute, blood pressure of 101/56 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and is being monitored for cardiac rhythm.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of cardiac injury, with elevated troponin-T levels and cardiac markers trending down. The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and the patient is being monitored for kidney function.

The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, chronic kidney disease, and obstructive sleep apnea. The patient is also taking medications for these conditions, including antihypertensives, statins, and a beta blocker.

The patient's physical examination is significant for a holosystolic murmur at the left upper sternal border, which may indicate mitral valve involvement. The patient's abdomen is soft and normoactive, and the patient's extremities are warm and dry.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac markers are trending down, but the patient may still be at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest.
2. Kidney complications: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and the patient may be at risk for acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease progression.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient is receiving oxygen therapy, and the patient may be at risk for respiratory failure or respiratory arrest.
4. Neurological complications: The patient is at risk for delirium or toxic encephalopathy, and the patient may require further evaluation and treatment.
5. Vascular complications: The patient has a history of peripheral vascular disease and may be at risk for vascular complications, such as graft occlusion or bleeding.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal disease and may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose levels are elevated, and the patient may be at risk for hyperglycemia or diabetic ketoacidosis.

Based on this information, the patient's treatment plan should include close monitoring of cardiac and kidney function, as well as management of the patient's underlying medical conditions. The patient should also be evaluated for potential complications and treated accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for a posterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and acute on chronic heart failure (CHF). He has also undergone femoral-popliteal bypass surgery for severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD).

The patient's current condition is stable, with no recurrent episodes of chest pain since weaning off nitroglycerin and discontinuing heparin. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 64 beats per minute, blood pressure of 106/66 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. He is able to tolerate oral medications and has been uptitrated on imdur and metoprolol.

However, the patient is at risk for several potential medical complications, including:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of CAD, STEMI, and CHF, which puts him at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac rupture.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is at risk for respiratory complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory failure.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.
4. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his indwelling lines and tubes, as well as his history of recent surgery.
5. Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to his anticoagulant therapy and his history of recent surgery.
6. Renal complications: The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and is at risk for renal complications such as acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease progression.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a history of diabetes and is at risk for hyperglycemia due to his recent surgery and medications.
8. Hypotension: The patient is at risk for hypotension due to his antihypertensive medications and his history of recent surgery.

To mitigate these risks, the patient should be closely monitored for any signs of complications, and his medications should be adjusted as necessary. He should also be encouraged to participate in his care and to ask questions about his condition and treatment.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be determined:

**Summary:**

The patient, a 70-year-old male with a history of CAD, diastolic heart failure, and severe PVD, is recovering from a posterior STEMI and femoral bypass surgery. He has been weaned off heparin and restarted on a diet. His chest pain has been controlled, and he has been uptitrated on IMdur and metoprolol. He has been experiencing some lightheadedness and orthostatic hypotension. His Hct has been trending down, and he has been typed and cross-matched. He has been experiencing some gastrointestinal issues, including diarrhea and constipation.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient's history of CAD, diastolic heart failure, and posterior STEMI puts him at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, and cardiogenic shock.
2. **Renal Complications:** The patient's history of CKD and Cr elevation at baseline puts him at risk for acute kidney injury and further deterioration of his renal function.
3. **Pulmonary Complications:** The patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and pneumonia puts him at risk for pulmonary complications such as respiratory failure, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
4. **Gastrointestinal Complications:** The patient's history of gastrointestinal issues such as diarrhea and constipation puts him at risk for further gastrointestinal complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.
5. **Hematological Complications:** The patient's history of anemia and low Hct puts him at risk for further hematological complications such as bleeding, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.
6. **Neurological Complications:** The patient's history of lightheadedness and orthostatic hypotension puts him at risk for further neurological complications such as syncope, seizures, and stroke.
7. **Infectious Complications:** The patient's history of pneumonia and antibiotics puts him at risk for further infectious complications such as sepsis, septic shock, and multi-organ failure.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac, renal, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, hematological, neurological, and infectious status.
2. Adjust medications as needed to manage the patient's symptoms and prevent complications.
3. Consider adding cholestyramine to the patient's medication regimen to help control his hypercholesterolemia.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's Hct and consider transfusing blood products if necessary.
5. Consider adding prophylactic antibiotics to the patient's medication regimen to prevent further infections.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and consider adding medications to help manage his lightheadedness and orthostatic hypotension.
7. Consider adding medications to help manage the patient's gastrointestinal issues such as diarrhea and constipation.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient has been weaned off nitroglycerin and heparin, and their diet has been restarted without recurrent episodes of chest pain. Their chest X-ray showed possible changes, but they remained afebrile with no white count elevation, so monitoring will continue clinically. The patient's I/O check showed a fluid balance of -1400cc.

The patient's medication has been uptitrated, including Imurid to 60mg PO BID and metoprolol to 25mg TID. They have also been titrated to chair during the day, remaining oriented when their wife is present.

The patient's hemoglobin has been trending down from 41.9 on admission to 32.6, and they have been typed and crossed.

The patient has a history of allergies to Lipitor, Ciprofloxacin, Trimethoprim, Bactrim, Atenolol, Crestor, Zetia, Vicodin, Cephalexin, Amlodipine, Quinapril, and Spironolactone.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a Tmax of 37.1C, Tcurrent of 37.1C, HR of 64 bpm, BP of 106/66 mmHg, RR of 22 inspirations per minute, and SpO2 of 98%.

The patient's laboratory results show a WBC count of 14.7, Hct of 32.6%, and Plt of 54. Their Cr is 1.5 mg/dL, TropT is 8.83, and glucose is 134 mg/dL.

The patient has been diagnosed with coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, and delirium/confusion. They are receiving ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Recurrent episodes of chest pain
* Hemodynamic instability
* Fluid overload
* Infection (e.g., pneumonia, urinary tract infection)
* Delirium/confusion worsening
* Worsening of peripheral vascular disease
* Development of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease
* Electrolyte imbalance (e.g., hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia)
* Worsening of glucose control
* Development of pressure ulcers or skin breakdown
* Infection or sepsis from central lines or other invasive devices.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, s/p coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diastolic heart failure, and severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He was admitted for femoral bypass and presented with post-operative posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and acute-on-chronic heart failure.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Chest pain has been weaned off nitroglycerin and remains pain-free.
* Heparin infusion was discontinued due to the patient's lack of recurrent episodes of chest pain.
* The patient is being uptitrated on imdur and metoprolol.
* The patient is able to get out of bed and remain oriented when his wife is present.
* His hemoglobin (Hb) level is trending down, and he is being typed and cross-matched for transfusion.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current status include:

* Recurrent episodes of chest pain due to graft occlusion or other cardiac issues.
* Worsening of heart failure symptoms, such as increased shortness of breath or swelling.
* Development of delirium or toxic encephalopathy due to medication or other underlying conditions.
* Increased risk of bleeding due to the discontinuation of heparin infusion.
* Potential for hypotension or hypertension due to changes in medication or other underlying conditions.
* Worsening of kidney function due to the patient's pre-existing chronic kidney disease (CKD) and potential for contrast-induced nephropathy.
* Potential for respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), due to the patient's underlying heart disease and possible respiratory failure.
* Potential for gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation, due to the patient's underlying PVD and possible gastrointestinal ischemia.

Based on the patient's current status, it is recommended that he continue to receive close monitoring and management of his cardiac, respiratory, and renal function.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of coronary artery disease, diastolic heart failure, and severe peripheral vascular disease. He underwent a femoral bypass procedure and developed a post-operative posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) with acute on chronic heart failure. He was treated with nitroglycerin and heparin infusions, and underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with placement of two bare metal stents.

The patient's condition has improved over the past 24 hours, with resolution of chest pain and a decrease in cardiac markers. He has been weaned off nitroglycerin and heparin infusions, and has been started on aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol. His blood pressure has been controlled with captopril, and he has been diuresed to a goal of 500 mL negative.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Recurrent graft occlusion: Given the patient's history of recurrent graft occlusion, there is a risk of further occlusion of the stents, which could lead to recurrent chest pain and heart failure.
2. Heart failure: The patient's heart failure is still present, and there is a risk of further decompensation, which could lead to increased morbidity and mortality.
3. Delirium: The patient is at risk for delirium due to his ICU stay and medications, which could lead to increased confusion, agitation, and risk of falls.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is borderline, and there is a risk of further hypertension, which could lead to increased cardiovascular risk.
5. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's hypercholesterolemia is poorly controlled, and there is a risk of further hypercholesterolemia, which could lead to increased cardiovascular risk.
6. Chronic kidney disease: The patient's chronic kidney disease is still present, and there is a risk of further kidney damage, which could lead to increased morbidity and mortality.
7. Obstructive sleep apnea: The patient has a history of obstructive sleep apnea, and there is a risk of further exacerbation, which could lead to increased cardiovascular risk.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac markers and adjust treatment as needed.
2. Continue to optimize the patient's heart failure treatment, including diuresis and vasodilators.
3. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further hypertension.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's hypercholesterolemia and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further hypercholesterolemia.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's chronic kidney disease and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further kidney damage.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's obstructive sleep apnea and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further exacerbation.

Summary:

The patient, a 70-year-old male, is a post-cardiac arrest patient who underwent a femoral-popliteal bypass procedure and developed a posterior STEMI. He was treated with PCI and two bare metal stents were placed. The patient is currently in the ICU, where he has been weaned off nitroglycerin and heparin, and has been uptitrated on his beta blocker and ACE inhibitor. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 64 bpm, blood pressure of 106/66 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. His physical examination is unremarkable, except for a slight decrease in his hematocrit.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiovascular complications: Given the patient's history of cardiac arrest and STEMI, there is a risk of further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or recurrent MI.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there is a risk of respiratory failure or pneumonia, particularly given his history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
3. Renal complications: The patient has chronic kidney disease (CKD), and there is a risk of acute kidney injury (AKI) or worsening of his CKD.
4. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of nocturnal disorientation, which may be related to his cardiac arrest or other underlying medical conditions. There is a risk of further neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.
5. Infection: The patient has a risk of infection, particularly given his history of vascular surgery and the use of indwelling catheters.
6. Bleeding complications: The patient has a risk of bleeding complications, particularly given his history of anticoagulation therapy and the use of antiplatelet agents.
7. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is borderline, and there is a risk of hypotension, particularly given his history of cardiac arrest and the use of vasodilators.
8. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is slightly elevated, and there is a risk of hyperkalemia, particularly given his history of CKD and the use of potassium-sparing diuretics.

Overall, the patient is at risk for a range of medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), femoral-popliteal bypass, and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for acute occlusion of the saphenous vein graft-omental (SVG-OM1) with placement of two bare metal stents (BMS). He is currently admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for post-operative management.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.8F (37.1C), heart rate of 64 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure of 106/66 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute (bpm). His oxygen saturation is 98% on 3 liters of oxygen.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 14.7-10.3 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 10.8-9.6 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 54 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.7-1.4 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 8.83 ng/mL
* Glucose: 134-99 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination is stable, with no signs of infection, and his neurological examination is normal.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Coronary artery disease (CAD)
* Diastolic heart failure
* Severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD)
* Post-operative posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
* Acute on chronic diastolic/acute systolic congestive heart failure (CHF)
* Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
* Hypercholesterolemia
* Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)
* History of femoral-popliteal bypass

The patient's medications include:

* Aspirin (ASA)
* Plavix
* Simvastatin
* Metoprolol
* Amlodipine
* Quinapril
* Ranitidine
* Furosemide
* Lasix
* Haldol
* Captopril

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Delirium
* Toxic encephalopathy
* Hypertension
* Rhythm disturbances
* Wound infection
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Renal failure
* Hyperglycemia

The patient's plan includes:

* Uptitration of beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors for further afterload reduction
* Monitoring for adverse reactions to statin therapy
* Consideration of cholestyramine as an alternative to statin therapy
* Diuresis goal of 500 mL negative
* Weaning of oxygen as tolerated
* Use of atrovent nebs as needed
* Monitoring of creatinine and urine output
* Consideration of cholestyramine for hypercholesterolemia
* Continued monitoring of the patient's condition and adjustments to his medications and treatment plan as necessary.
